description: Supreme constitutional constraints governing all child welfare actions. These constraints supersede federal, state, and administrative rules and serve as the highest-order legal authority.

constraints.name: Fourth Amendment – Seizure of Persons
constraints.text: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated…
constraints.application_to_cps: Removal of a child from parental custody constitutes a seizure under the Fourth Amendment. Absent consent or exigent circumstances involving imminent danger of serious bodily harm, removal requires prior judicial authorization (warrant or court order).

key_cases.name: Tenenbaum v. Williams
key_cases.court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
key_cases.holding: Temporary removal of a child constitutes a Fourth Amendment seizure; emergency removal without prior court authorization is permissible only where officials have reasonable cause to believe the child faces imminent danger.

key_cases.name: Gates v. Texas Dept. of Protective & Regulatory Services
key_cases.court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
key_cases.holding: Fourth Amendment applies to child welfare investigations; warrantless home entry and child removal require consent or exigent circumstances. Defendants were granted qualified immunity due to lack of clearly established law on the specific facts.

key_cases.name: Roska v. Peterson
key_cases.court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
key_cases.holding: Removal of children from their home without a warrant violates the Fourth Amendment unless exigent circumstances are present; exigency is narrowly construed.

requirements.exigency_standard: Imminent danger of serious bodily harm

constraints.name: Fourth Amendment – Search of the Home
constraints.text: …no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation…
constraints.application_to_cps: Home entry, inspection, or investigation by child welfare officials constitutes a search under the Fourth Amendment. Consent must be voluntary and uncoerced; refusal alone cannot justify entry.

key_cases.name: Calabretta v. Floyd
key_cases.court: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
key_cases.holding: Warrantless CPS entry into a home absent consent or exigent circumstances violates the Fourth Amendment; social workers are not exempt from constitutional limits.

key_cases.name: Walsh v. Erie County Dept. of Job and Family Services
key_cases.holding: Threatening removal of children to obtain consent renders consent involuntary under the Fourth Amendment.

constraints.violation_remedy: 42 U.S.C. § 1983; exclusion of unlawfully obtained evidence

constraints.name: Fourteenth Amendment – Procedural Due Process
constraints.text: …nor shall any State deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law…
constraints.application_to_cps: Parents possess a constitutionally protected liberty interest in the care, custody, and control of their children. Before deprivation, due process requires notice, a meaningful opportunity to be heard, and a neutral decision-maker. Emergency removals require a prompt post-deprivation hearing within a constitutionally reasonable time.

key_cases.name: Mathews v. Eldridge
key_cases.holding: Established a three-factor balancing test to determine what procedural due process requires in a given context.

key_cases.name: Santosky v. Kramer
key_cases.holding: Termination of parental rights requires proof by clear and convincing evidence.

key_cases.name: Stanley v. Illinois
key_cases.holding: Parents are entitled to a hearing on fitness before the state may remove children; unfitness cannot be presumed.

constraints.violation_remedy: 42 U.S.C. § 1983; reversal of orders entered without due process

constraints.name: Fourteenth Amendment – Substantive Due Process (Family Integrity)
constraints.text: …nor shall any State deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law…
constraints.application_to_cps: The right to family integrity is a fundamental liberty interest. State interference must be justified by a compelling interest in child safety and must be narrowly tailored to achieve that interest.

key_cases.name: Troxel v. Granville
key_cases.holding: Parents have a fundamental right to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children.

key_cases.name: Meyer v. Nebraska
key_cases.holding: Liberty protected by the Fourteenth Amendment includes the right to establish a home and bring up children.

key_cases.name: Pierce v. Society of Sisters
key_cases.holding: The state may not unreasonably interfere with parents’ liberty to direct the upbringing and education of children.

constraints.violation_remedy: 42 U.S.C. § 1983; damages for unconstitutional family separation

constraints.name: Fifth Amendment – Self-Incrimination
constraints.text: …nor shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself…
constraints.application_to_cps: Parents may not be compelled to provide testimonial statements that could incriminate them in criminal proceedings. Invocation of the Fifth Amendment may not be penalized in dependency proceedings. Production of a child pursuant to a lawful custodial order does not waive testimonial protections.

key_cases.name: Lefkowitz v. Cunningham
key_cases.holding: The state may not impose substantial penalties for exercising the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.

key_cases.name: Baltimore City Dept. of Social Services v. Bouknight
key_cases.holding: A parent subject to a valid custodial order may be compelled to produce the child, but the Fifth Amendment continues to protect against compelled testimonial self-incrimination.
